content:
Starting With High Hopes I signed up for the Jakarta 150 km Audax imagining a steady day in the saddle, easy pace, friendly banter at checkpoints, maybe even an iced kopi somewhere along the way. What I got was the exact opposite.
Heat, Flats, and Muddy Roads The sun showed up early and refused to leave. By kilometer 20 it felt like every pedal stroke was being grilled into the asphalt. And then, before I even made it to the first checkpoint, the rear tire went soft. No sag wagon, no neutral support, just me, my tools, and Jakarta heat turning every minute into a test of patience.
The GPX did not cut me any slack either, muddy backroads, gravel patches, and detours that chewed up both bike and rider.
Almost DNF Near Fatmawati About 5 km from Fatmawati Hospital I hit a low that surprised me. I just wanted to DNF. Everything in me wanted to stop. But there was also a strange, sudden happiness at being that close to the finish, like relief and disbelief mixed together. I told myself, I believe I can, and kept turning the pedals.
Snapped Chain, Stubborn Finish As if that was not enough, the chain snapped just 7 km from the finish. Greasy fingers, shaky hands, one spare link, somehow I managed to piece it back together. Unsupported means exactly that, no one is coming. So I kept rolling.
When I finally crossed the finish, jersey caked in salt and mind running on fumes, it felt like debugging life line by line, messy, frustrating, but worth every keystroke. Jakarta peeled me apart that day. Mud, busted chain, flat tire before checkpoint one, and the kind of heat that makes you hallucinate. But I still finished. That is the only line of code that matters.
summary:
Starting With High Hopes

I signed up for the Jakarta 150 km Audax imagining a steady day in the saddle, easy pace, friendly banter at checkpoints, maybe even an iced kopi somewhere along the way. What I got was the exact opposite.

Heat, Flats, and Muddy Roads

The sun showed up early and refused to leave. By kilometer 20 it felt like every pedal stroke was being grilled into the asphalt. And then, before I even made it to the first checkpoint, the rear tire went soft. No sag wagon, no neutral support, just me, my tools, and Jakarta heat turning every minute into a test of patience.
title: Audax 150KM Jakarta: Unsupported and Unbroken

content:
Ramadhan Stories A few months back, around Ramadan, I stumbled into an anime I totally misjudged.
Thought it was some weird horror or action thing (title had Orb in it, so yeah, I expected punching or blood or something like that).
Turns out… it was about geocentric vs. heliocentric theory.
Earth-centered vs. Sun-centered.
And the madness people faced when they tried to prove something the world wasnâ€™t ready to accept.
Didnâ€™t expect to feel anything.
Instead, I got wrecked.
It felt too real Watching someone dedicate their entire life to a truth and still get rejected … damn.
That broke something inside me.
It felt too real. Like the kind of pain you canâ€™t argue with â€” the pain of being right, too early.
My Mind went elsewhere And suddenly, my mind went elsewhere.
I started thinking about Prophet Muhammad ï·º.
He wasnâ€™t trying to prove planets move.
He was trying to guide hearts.
Things we’re still figuring out He didnâ€™t come with formulas or telescopes.
But the Qurâ€™an talks about the cosmos, the heavens, the universe expanding, and yeah … things weâ€™re still figuring out.
And then thereâ€™s Isra Miâ€™raj.
A journey through the heavens.
Outside of time, outside of reason, and yet… it happened.
He came back with prayer. Not theories.
And I thought:
He couldâ€™ve had peace. A quiet life.
But he chose the heavy path .. for us.
Science & Faith That anime made me feel a lot.
Like… science and faith donâ€™t have to fight.
Sometimes they meet.
In a verse. In a telescope. In a broken moment.
Or yeah, even in some random anime at 2AM during Ramadan ğŸ˜…
Truth â€” whether uncovered through research, or held by faith â€”
it’s still truth
and it still shines.
Thanks for being here.
That moment during Ramadan still lingers in my head.
Sometimes, the most meaningful things come from places you werenâ€™t even looking.
still me,
Agung âœ¨s
summary:
Ramadhan Stories

A few months back, around Ramadan, I stumbled into an anime I totally misjudged.
Thought it was some weird horror or action thing (title had Orb in it, so yeah, I expected punching or blood or something like that).

Turns out… it was about geocentric vs. heliocentric theory.
Earth-centered vs. Sun-centered.
And the madness people faced when they tried to prove something the world wasnâ€™t ready to accept.

content:
It all started with Patrick â€”
Not a person. A bike.
A junk Chinese gravel bike I bought for 600K from the cursed depths of Shitpee (yeah, Shopee)
Before it was Patrick, it was just… tragic.
White frame.
Shitty red decals that looked like knock-off fire graphics.
I thought stickers would save it.
So I went full Jaksel-core: anime, fake brands, nonsense logos.
It looked worse.
But I donâ€™t know whyâ€¦
I loved that damn bike.
Maybe because it didnâ€™t care what it looked like.
It just kept rolling â€” no questions asked.
Then came the pain rides:
Audax 200KM â€” finished, but missed the cut-off. Still proud. JBR (Jakarta Bronx Border Ride) â€” my legs never forgave me, where bike lanes go to die. GXID a.k.a Jakarta Ride â€” routes designed by psychopaths with GPS. Depok U-Series â€” 130KM + 1300m elev. For fun? Nope. For trauma. After all that, I said:
“You know what, this frame deserves better.”
So I called Psychloop in Darmawangsa:
â€œBro, repaint this thing. Name it Patrick.â€
Boom. Patrick was born.
A fresh coat of class over years of chaos.
While I was there, I made the dumbest smart move:
Bought MKS Solution pedals â€” pure Japan smoothness.
2x the price of the MXL frame.
Worth it?
Financially, no.
Spiritually? Yes.
Patrickâ€™s Final Form: GRX 10-speed ğŸ› ï¸ Entity Expert 400mm dropbar (clearance steal from Rodalink ğŸ™) Dia-Compe bar-end shifters (retro + regret = realness) TRP Spyre mechanical disc brakes WTB 700x37 tires (thicc, slow, dramatic) Repainted & reborn as Patrick by Psychloop MKS Solution pedals (because why not go bankrupt?) 600K MXL frame that survived hell and paint What I Learned: Donâ€™t upgrade trashâ€¦ unless you want a story Love makes you do dumb things â€” like $80 pedals on a $40 frame Stickers donâ€™t fix ugly Gravel â‰  comfort Dumb bikes + dumber owners = beautiful chaos Dumb bike. Dumber owner. Still riding.
ğŸ’š Still broke. Still proud. Still here.

It all started with Patrick â€”
Not a person. A bike.
A junk Chinese gravel bike I bought for 600K from the cursed depths of Shitpee (yeah, Shopee)

Before it was Patrick, it was just… tragic.
White frame.

Shitty red decals that looked like knock-off fire graphics.
I thought stickers would save it.
So I went full Jaksel-core: anime, fake brands, nonsense logos.
It looked worse.

But I donâ€™t know whyâ€¦
I loved that damn bike.
Maybe because it didnâ€™t care what it looked like.
It just kept rolling â€” no questions asked.

content:
Why It Wasnâ€™t What I Expected For as long as I can remember, I thought life was supposed to follow a straight line. You pick a dream when youâ€™re youngâ€”astronaut, architect, rockstar, whateverâ€”and then you chase it down, step by step. Thatâ€™s what weâ€™re told, anyway.
But hereâ€™s what nobody tells you: most of us end up somewhere completely different. We blink, years pass, and suddenly weâ€™re not the people we once imagined.
Staring at the Mirror (And Not Recognizing Whoâ€™s There) Iâ€™ve had more than a few moments where I looked in the mirror and thought, â€œWho is this?â€
Not in a dramatic, movie-meltdown kind of wayâ€”just a quiet, subtle sense of not recognizing the version of myself looking back.
Every era of my life feels like it belonged to a different person:
The one who thought heâ€™d be an esports player or a band player. The one who ended up in digital marketing, which was never on my vision board. The one who got back into coding after years away. The cyclist, chasing sunrise rides and sore legs instead ofâ€¦ whatever I thought adulthood was supposed to be. The Unexpected Turns I never set out to be a digital marketer.
I didnâ€™t imagine Iâ€™d be the kind of person who finds joy in analytics dashboards or debugging someoneâ€™s messy code at midnight.
And I definitely never saw myself obsessing over cycling gear, logging kilometers like I was training for the Tour de France.
Sometimes I wonder if Iâ€™m living in someone elseâ€™s bodyâ€”a stranger who just happens to share my name and a few old memories.
Losing and Finding â€œYouâ€ Songs like Bowieâ€™s The Man Who Sold the World or Gotyeâ€™s Somebody That I Used to Know hit me because theyâ€™re about exactly this:
Looking back and seeing a stranger in your own story. Wondering if you â€œsold out,â€ or just grew up. If you lost control, or simply changed.
We all become â€œsomebody I used to knowâ€ at some point, and thatâ€™s okay.
The Truth: Youâ€™re Always Becoming If Iâ€™ve learned anything, itâ€™s this: finding yourself isnâ€™t a destination.
Itâ€™s a constant, messy, beautiful process of becomingâ€”letting go of the old versions and meeting the new ones, over and over.
Some days I miss the person I thought Iâ€™d be.
Most days, though, Iâ€™m grateful for the one Iâ€™ve becomeâ€”even if I had no idea he was coming.
Because in the end, you donâ€™t find yourself all at once.
You find yourself a little bit every day, in every surprise, every detour, every mirror.
summary:
Why It Wasnâ€™t What I Expected

For as long as I can remember, I thought life was supposed to follow a straight line. You pick a dream when youâ€™re youngâ€”astronaut, architect, rockstar, whateverâ€”and then you chase it down, step by step. Thatâ€™s what weâ€™re told, anyway.

But hereâ€™s what nobody tells you: most of us end up somewhere completely different. We blink, years pass, and suddenly weâ€™re not the people we once imagined.
title: How I Found Myself

content:
I donâ€™t even know where to start. Maybe this blog exists out of ego. Maybe itâ€™s just me trying to fix the mess I made with rasastroberiâ€”a blog I once loved, hated, and at one point thought about killing (along with the part of me that made it). Or maybe itâ€™s an attempt to bury alkind_COOLâ€”a name so cringe I still flinch thinking about it.
Anywayâ€¦ Iâ€™m glad you’re here. This space, agungsukariman.com, is gonna be my place to dump thoughts. Iâ€™ll talk about digital marketing, tech stuff, dead or dying SEO tricks, tools I like, music I listen to, things Iâ€™m building, breaking, or obsessed with. Nothing too formal. Just notes from my head to yours.
Letâ€™s see where this goes.

title: Call Me

content:
The truth is, Agung was never meant to be my name. My mom wanted Agus â€” you know, the classic Indo name, mass-produced like mie instan ğŸœ. But maybe thatâ€™s the problem. Too many Aguses walking around. So my dad came through with Agung. Sounds like some Bali prince or gamelan prodigyâ€¦ but nope. Just me. Not Balinese. Justâ€¦ here.
Sukariman? Thatâ€™s a whole other drama.
SU from Sulastri, my mom â€” the real MVP.
KARIM, from the Karim family, who literally picked baby me up from the hospital when my parents were broke. No grab, no gojek, just pure kindness â¤ï¸
And MAN? Thatâ€™s for Basman, my dad. Or as I like to call itâ€¦ Bestman. Lols.
So yeah, even my name is a mashup of love, struggle, and last-minute decisions ğŸ²
I was supposed to be in a band ğŸ¸. Or an esports team ğŸ®. Or I dunno, doing something that didnâ€™t involve debugging tracking scripts at 2am. Not to mention that one dream â€” becoming a Game Master at Netmarble. Yup. I really thought I’d be managing MMORPG servers, banning cheaters, and giving away item codes like Oprah. Life said nope.
But here I am â€” writing, clicking, optimizing pixels, and biking long rides ğŸš´â€â™‚ï¸ like Iâ€™m running away from my own roadmap.
Sometimes I look in the mirror and think: am I really living the life I thought I would? Probably not. But at least Iâ€™m still moving. Still me. Just weirder now.
This blog? Donâ€™t expect perfection. Expect detours, noise, unfinished thoughts, and maybe a few dead jokes along the way ğŸ’€
